issue.title: [YSQL] Very low performance in graph traversal with recursive CTEs

labels.name: kind/enhancement
labels.description: This is an enhancement of an existing feature

issue.body:
Jira Link: [DB-7520](https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-7520)
### Description

Hi everyone,

in our performance evaluation of Yugabyte versus plain Postgres and other competitors we experienced very low performance with recursive CTEs on larger tables. The test is derived by your [examples on graph traversal](https://docs.yugabyte.com/preview/api/ysql/the-sql-language/with-clause/traversing-general-graphs/).  For testing purposes this was done on a single node docker instance, but a quick test on a multi-node setup revealed similar results.

### Setup

The minimal setup consists of a directed acyclic graph represented by an edges table:

```sql
CREATE TABLE edges (
    id UUID PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL,
    origin UUID,
    target UUID,
);
CREATE INDEX ot_idx ON edges (origin, target);
CREATE INDEX to_idx ON edges (target, origin);
```

The graph has a maximum depth of 4 layers (3 edges) and consists of approximately 2,2 Million rows mixed between one, two and three edges. 

### Problem

The problem arises when these paths are queried via recursive CTEs like so:

```sql
WITH RECURSIVE paths AS (
    SELECT origin, target
    FROM edges WHERE target_pid = $1 
  UNION ALL 
    SELECT e.origin, e.target
    FROM paths, edges e WHERE e.target = paths.origin
) SELECT * FROM paths;
```

I expect this to use the indices  to speed up the query and in fact if I dump this exact setup on a vanilla postgres instance this is the case:

#### `EXPLAIN ANALYZE` postgres

```sql
CTE Scan on paths  (cost=454.22..456.24 rows=101 width=32) (actual time=0.035..0.071 rows=3 loops=1)
   CTE paths
     ->  Recursive Union  (cost=0.43..454.22 rows=101 width=32) (actual time=0.034..0.070 rows=3 loops=1)
           ->  Index Only Scan using to_idx on edges  (cost=0.43..4.45 rows=1 width=32) (actual time=0.033..0.033 rows=1 loops=1)
                 Index Cond: (target_pid = '<SOME-PID>'::uuid)
                 Heap Fetches: 0
           ->  Nested Loop  (cost=0.43..44.77 rows=10 width=32) (actual time=0.011..0.011 rows=1 loops=3)
                 ->  WorkTable Scan on paths paths_1  (cost=0.00..0.20 rows=10 width=16) (actual time=0.000..0.000 rows=1 loops=3)
                 ->  Index Only Scan using to_idx on edges e  (cost=0.43..4.45 rows=1 width=32) (actual time=0.009..0.010 rows=1 loops=3)
                       Index Cond: (e.target = paths_1.origin)
                       Heap Fetches: 0
 Planning Time: 0.243 ms
 Execution Time: 0.110 ms
 ```

The same query on Yugabyte however takes forever because it uses multiple seq scans instead of the index:

#### `EXPLAIN ANALYZE` yugabyte

```sql
 CTE Scan on paths  (cost=4195826.03..4636656.69 rows=22041533 width=32) (actual time=0.494..15469.336 rows=3 loops=1)
   CTE paths
     ->  Recursive Union  (cost=0.00..4195826.03 rows=22041533 width=32) (actual time=0.493..15469.331 rows=3 loops=1)
           ->  Index Only Scan using to_idx on edges  (cost=0.00..24555.24 rows=218233 width=32) (actual time=0.491..0.492 rows=1 loops=1)
                 Index Cond: (target = '<SOME-PID>'::uuid)
                 Heap Fetches: 0
           ->  Hash Join  (cost=260431.46..373044.01 rows=2182330 width=32) (actual time=5150.801..5156.240 rows=1 loops=3)
                 Hash Cond: (paths_1.origin = e.target)
                 ->  WorkTable Scan on paths paths_1  (cost=0.00..43646.60 rows=2182330 width=16) (actual time=0.001..0.001 rows=1 loops=3)
                 ->  Hash  (cost=218233.30..218233.30 rows=2182333 width=32) (actual time=5138.620..5138.620 rows=2182333 loops=3)
                       Buckets: 65536  Batches: 64  Memory Usage: 2635kB
                       ->  Seq Scan on edges e  (cost=0.00..218233.30 rows=2182333 width=32) (actual time=2.339..4740.180 rows=2182333 loops=3)
 Planning Time: 0.134 ms
 Execution Time: 15469.442 ms
 Peak Memory Usage: 5239 kB
```

Are we doing something wrong here ? Is there a chance to speed this up, or is this a known issue with Yugabyte ? A quick search revealed nothing useful. 

Thanks in advance!

### Warning: Please confirm that this issue does not contain any sensitive information

- [X] I confirm this issue does not contain any sensitive information.

[DB-7520]: https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-7520?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiNWRkNTljNzYxNjVmNDY3MDlhMDU5Y2ZhYzA5YTRkZjUiLCJwIjoiZ2l0aHViLWNvbS1KU1cifQ

issue.title: [YSQL] Very low performance in graph traversal with recursive CTEs

labels.name: kind/enhancement
labels.description: This is an enhancement of an existing feature

issue.body:
Jira Link: [DB-7520](https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-7520)
### Description

Hi everyone,

in our performance evaluation of Yugabyte versus plain Postgres and other competitors we experienced very low performance with recursive CTEs on larger tables. The test is derived by your [examples on graph traversal](https://docs.yugabyte.com/preview/api/ysql/the-sql-language/with-clause/traversing-general-graphs/).  For testing purposes this was done on a single node docker instance, but a quick test on a multi-node setup revealed similar results.

### Setup

The minimal setup consists of a directed acyclic graph represented by an edges table:

```sql
CREATE TABLE edges (
    id UUID PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL,
    origin UUID,
    target UUID,
);
CREATE INDEX ot_idx ON edges (origin, target);
CREATE INDEX to_idx ON edges (target, origin);
```

The graph has a maximum depth of 4 layers (3 edges) and consists of approximately 2,2 Million rows mixed between one, two and three edges. 

### Problem

The problem arises when these paths are queried via recursive CTEs like so:

```sql
WITH RECURSIVE paths AS (
    SELECT origin, target
    FROM edges WHERE target_pid = $1 
  UNION ALL 
    SELECT e.origin, e.target
    FROM paths, edges e WHERE e.target = paths.origin
) SELECT * FROM paths;
```

I expect this to use the indices  to speed up the query and in fact if I dump this exact setup on a vanilla postgres instance this is the case:

#### `EXPLAIN ANALYZE` postgres

```sql
CTE Scan on paths  (cost=454.22..456.24 rows=101 width=32) (actual time=0.035..0.071 rows=3 loops=1)
   CTE paths
     ->  Recursive Union  (cost=0.43..454.22 rows=101 width=32) (actual time=0.034..0.070 rows=3 loops=1)
           ->  Index Only Scan using to_idx on edges  (cost=0.43..4.45 rows=1 width=32) (actual time=0.033..0.033 rows=1 loops=1)
                 Index Cond: (target_pid = '<SOME-PID>'::uuid)
                 Heap Fetches: 0
           ->  Nested Loop  (cost=0.43..44.77 rows=10 width=32) (actual time=0.011..0.011 rows=1 loops=3)
                 ->  WorkTable Scan on paths paths_1  (cost=0.00..0.20 rows=10 width=16) (actual time=0.000..0.000 rows=1 loops=3)
                 ->  Index Only Scan using to_idx on edges e  (cost=0.43..4.45 rows=1 width=32) (actual time=0.009..0.010 rows=1 loops=3)
                       Index Cond: (e.target = paths_1.origin)
                       Heap Fetches: 0
 Planning Time: 0.243 ms
 Execution Time: 0.110 ms
 ```

The same query on Yugabyte however takes forever because it uses multiple seq scans instead of the index:

#### `EXPLAIN ANALYZE` yugabyte

```sql
 CTE Scan on paths  (cost=4195826.03..4636656.69 rows=22041533 width=32) (actual time=0.494..15469.336 rows=3 loops=1)
   CTE paths
     ->  Recursive Union  (cost=0.00..4195826.03 rows=22041533 width=32) (actual time=0.493..15469.331 rows=3 loops=1)
           ->  Index Only Scan using to_idx on edges  (cost=0.00..24555.24 rows=218233 width=32) (actual time=0.491..0.492 rows=1 loops=1)
                 Index Cond: (target = '<SOME-PID>'::uuid)
                 Heap Fetches: 0
           ->  Hash Join  (cost=260431.46..373044.01 rows=2182330 width=32) (actual time=5150.801..5156.240 rows=1 loops=3)
                 Hash Cond: (paths_1.origin = e.target)
                 ->  WorkTable Scan on paths paths_1  (cost=0.00..43646.60 rows=2182330 width=16) (actual time=0.001..0.001 rows=1 loops=3)
                 ->  Hash  (cost=218233.30..218233.30 rows=2182333 width=32) (actual time=5138.620..5138.620 rows=2182333 loops=3)
                       Buckets: 65536  Batches: 64  Memory Usage: 2635kB
                       ->  Seq Scan on edges e  (cost=0.00..218233.30 rows=2182333 width=32) (actual time=2.339..4740.180 rows=2182333 loops=3)
 Planning Time: 0.134 ms
 Execution Time: 15469.442 ms
 Peak Memory Usage: 5239 kB
```

Are we doing something wrong here ? Is there a chance to speed this up, or is this a known issue with Yugabyte ? A quick search revealed nothing useful. 

Thanks in advance!

commits.message:
[BACKPORT 2.20][#16177] docdb: mechanisms to reject table creation requests based on cluster resources

Summary:
Original commit: f50d214a0503b1defbc7f01d93e0595bffbf35fa / D26588
Initial diff to reject create table requests if the number of tablet replicas after successful table creation would be too high. Adds 3 flags:

  - `tablet_replicas_per_gib_limit` number of tablet replicas the cluster can support per GiB reserved for tablet overheads on a tserver. Master flag.
  - `tablet_replicas_per_core_limit` number of tablet replicas the cluster can support per core on a node with a running tserver. Master flag.
  - `tablet_overhead_size_percentage` amount of memory in bytes reserved for tablet-related overheads by each tserver. TServer flag.

These flags are currently test flags but they will be changed to auto flags once this feature is ready for GA.

This diff doesn't implement the algorithm for supporting placement-aware limits. There's some contention over whether or not to implement that feature.

Support for read placements will be added in a follow up diff.

This diff renames the `Tablets` memory tracker to `Tablets_overhead` to clarify what the memory tracker tracks.

In order to use the memory limit, every tserver needs to set `tablet_overhead_size_percentage` to a positive value and the master must have a positive value for `tablet_replicas_per_gib_limit`. In order to use the core limit, the master must have a positive value for `tablet_replicas_per_core_limit`.

**Proto changes**
This diff adds the `ResourcesPB resources` field to the `TSRegistrationPB` protobuf. This protobuf is sent from tservers to masters as a part of the heartbeat RPC and is saved as in-memory state by the leader master. The `ResourcesPB` proto has two fields, one to track memory dedicated to tablet overheads and one to track cores.

The tserver sets the new core field unconditionally. It sets the memory field if a new flag, `tablet_overhead_size_percentage`, is set to an integer greater than 0 and less than or equal to 100.

If neither of the new master flags have been set to a non-default value, the master never reads these fields.
If one of the master flags has been set to a positive value, the master reads the corresponding field. For example when `tablet_replicas_per_gib_limit` has been set to 1000 the master will read the `ResourcesPB::tablet_overhead_ram_in_bytes` field. If any tserver has not set a resource field, then the corresponding resource is ignored when computing limits. For example, during an upgrade that includes this feature suppose there are 3 tservers, 2 have been upgraded and the leader master has been upgraded as well. The un-upgraded tserver will not set the `ResourcesPB` proto in its heartbeats so the limits will be ignored by the leader master.

**Upgrade/Rollback Safety**
This diff doesn't introduce any autoflags. The new flags should not be set because they are test only flags. The `TSRegistrationPB` protos this diff modifies are stored in the TSManager`'s `servers_by_id_` field. This field is not persisted.

 Assuming none of the flags introduced by this diff are set, the safety arguments are:

  - during an upgrade while the leader-master is on an older version it will simply ignore the new fields set by any upgraded tservers. Once the leader master has been upgraded to include this diff it will bail out of the new function `CanCreateTabletReplicas` early because both flags default to 0.
  - during a rollback the same reasoning applies.
Jira: DB-5610

Test Plan:
```
ybd --cxx-test tablet_limits_test
ybd --cxx-test tablet_limits_integration_test
```

Reviewers: slingam, mlillibridge, yyan, asrivastava

Reviewed By: asrivastava

Subscribers: slingam, bogdan, ybase, yql, mhaddad, hsunder

Tags: #jenkins-ready

Differential Revision: https://phorge.dev.yugabyte.com/D29590

issue.title: [New Feature] Faster Bulk-Data Loading in YugabyteDB

labels.name: kind/enhancement
labels.description: This is an enhancement of an existing feature

issue.body:
Jira Link: [DB-4641](https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-4641)
### Description

Master issue to track improvements to make it easier and faster to get large amounts of data into YugabyteDB.

###  Phase 1
| Status | Feature        | GitHub Issue | Comments |
| :--: | --------------- | ------------------  | ------------------ |
| ✅ | Faster non transactional writes during bulk load  | #7809 | Allowing faster writes on copy command by using session variable "yb_force_non_transactional_writes". |
| ✅ | Disable transactional writes during bulk data loading for indexes   | #11266|  Add yb_disable_transactional_writes session to improve the latency performance of bulk data loading for index tables such as when COPY command is used which goes into the insert write path (not delete or update).|
| ✅  |  Implement Async Flush for COPY command | #11628 | Currently, we synchronously wait for a flush response every time we flush. We want to make this asynchronous to reduce the time spent waiting and improve the performance of COPY.|
| ✅ | Speed up YSQL inserts by skipping lookup of keys being inserted | #11269 | During bulk load (for example inserts by Copy command), skip lookup of the key being inserted, to speed up the inserts. This is similar to the upsert mode that is supported for YCQL. |
| ✅  | Optimize memory allocation/deallocation in bulk insert/copy using Protobuf's arena | #11720 |  Currently when running bulk insert / copy command, in the PostgreSQL backend for, about 15 percent of CPU time is spent on memory allocation / deallocation.|
| ✅  | Perf improvement by eliminating serialization to the WAL format. | #11409 | When writing data to the RocksDb layer, there are additional steps of serializing to the WAL format which is unnecessary and leads to wasted work.|
| ✅  |  Tuning parameters for faster copy performance | #12293 | Tuning parameters for faster copy performance |
| ✅  | Pack columns in DocDB storage format for better performance| #3520 | Packing columns into a single RocksDB entry per row instead of one per column (as we do currently) improves YSQL performance |
| ⬜️  | Parallelize copy command | #11453 | Distribute copy operation internally using multiple workers |


###  Phase 2
| Status | Feature        | GitHub Issue | Comments |
| :--: | --------------- | ------------------  | ------------------ |
| ⬜️  |  Streaming ingest to YugabyteDB without using JDBC | |Inserting around 1 billion records through the streaming interface every day. It will be inefficient to transfer this huge volume of records over the JDBC interface. It could be implementing Spark RDD write interface.|

comment.body:
> Streaming ingest to YugabyteDB without using JDBC

Maybe https://www.postgresql.org/about/news/apache-arrow-flight-sql-adapter-for-postgresql-010-2716/ could be of use.

comment.body:
Hey @nodakai, This back-port would require to back-port fix for another issue as well because this issue\error bubbled up after we had fixed another issue. So we will prioritise this accordingly.
This has been fixed in 2.18.4.0, can you move to 2.18 or some other version where this fix is available?

issue.title: [YSQL] Why is ybbasectid the key of an index table?
issue.body:
Jira Link: [DB-8498](https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-8498)
### Description

Why is ybbasectid the key column of an index table, and is its query efficiency consistent with the efficiency of using ybctid to search a table?

```
table_name: "test1_embedding_idx"
schema {
  columns {
    id: 10
    name: "embedding"
    type {
      main: BINARY
    }
    is_key: true
    is_hash_key: true
    is_nullable: false
    is_static: false
    is_counter: false
    sorting_type: 0
    order: 1
    pg_type_oid: 0
  }
  columns {
    id: 11
    name: "ybidxbasectid"
    type {
      main: BINARY
    }
    is_key: true
    is_nullable: false
    is_static: false
    is_counter: false
    sorting_type: 1
    order: -101
    pg_type_oid: 0
  }
}
```



### Issue Type

kind/question

### Warning: Please confirm that this issue does not contain any sensitive information

- [X] I confirm this issue does not contain any sensitive information.

[DB-8498]: https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-8498?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiNWRkNTljNzYxNjVmNDY3MDlhMDU5Y2ZhYzA5YTRkZjUiLCJwIjoiZ2l0aHViLWNvbS1KU1cifQ

comment.body:
Yes, indexes are like tables, with the addition of this `ybidxbasectid` that references the table's row key.
What you are doing looks cool. I'll ping the colleagues who have been working on the YugabyteDB implementation of GIN indexes and who are looking at indexing for pgvector.  

We have also a #contributors slack channel at https://join.slack.com/t/yugabyte-db/shared_invite/zt-xbd652e9-3tN0N7UG0eLpsace4t1d2A

issue.title: [docs][PLAT-7408] Add details of certified Helm charts for OpenShift
issue.body:
This change adds instructions related to Red Hat certified Helm charts for OpenShift environment.
- Removes the operator based installation from preview as we never had preview releases of operator available.
- Deprecate the operator based installation on stable, it is not maintained and we don't have any users.

Have tested the instructions by following the steps on an OpenShift cluster.

This change adds instructions related to Red Hat certified Helm charts for OpenShift environment.
- Removes the operator based installation from preview as we never had preview releases of operator available.
- Deprecate the operator based installation on stable, it is not maintained and we don't have any users.

issue.title: [YSQL] Serializing CDC intent values for bytea columns as datum_bytes instead of datum_string
issue.body:
### Description

Currently bytea columns in YSQL are serialized as hex strings (datum_string) when pulled using the CDCSDK system. This incurs approximately a 2x overhead on the network I/O for that column. I have a system that uses an outbox pattern with which I want to stream bytes out of the system. Would this be hard to change?

### Issue Type

kind/enhancement

### Warning: Please confirm that this issue does not contain any sensitive information

- [X] I confirm this issue does not contain any sensitive information.

issue.title: [YSQL] Why is ybbasectid the key of an index table?
issue.body:
Jira Link: [DB-8498](https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-8498)
### Description

Why is ybbasectid the key column of an index table, and is its query efficiency consistent with the efficiency of using ybctid to search a table?

```
table_name: "test1_embedding_idx"

  columns {
    id: 10

      main: BINARY

    is_key: true
    is_hash_key: true

    is_static: false

    order: 1
    pg_type_oid: 0

comment.body:
> Can you explain more about this plug-in? I'm curious.
> 
> I've no idea what is BMCpgnewselect and how you access those internal columns but basically accessing with ybbasectid and without the index key columns cannot be efficient as it is a suffix.

In my current understanding, the index table of yb is the same concept as a common table. So I want to use index tables like a common table.However, the index table of pg is composed of index columns and containing columns, and users cannot flexibly customize the columns. This makes it difficult to introduce yb into some complex indexes, such as hnsw and ivf of pgvector. But if we can customize the columns of the index table, we can easily introduce these indexes. In fact, I am trying to do these things. In DefineIndex(), I forcefully constructed the structure of the hnsw index table using the if statement, and then stored the binary data of hnsw index.

```

  columns {
    id: 10
    name: "embedding"
    type {
      main: BINARY
    }
    is_key: true
    is_hash_key: true

    is_nullable: false

}

comment.body:
> In a non unique secondary index the ybbasectid (which is the ybctid of the table, the internal representation of its primary key) must be part of the key to have unique entries. It is at the end of the indexed columns so doesn't impact the range scan. And it is used to access the table's row to get the columns that are not in the index (in an Index Scan that is not an Index Only Scan)

 am currently trying to develop a plugin that requires updating one row of data in the index table. Can I use ybbasectid instead of index fields as the where condition (as the length of index fields may be large)? I tried using BMCpgnewselect and binding ybbasectid as the where condition to query the corresponding index data rows, it's ok. But when I used the same method to update, it would prompt me that the update must be bound to ybctid or primary key.

And I want to know if using ybbasectid as the where condition to filter a certain row in the index table would be very efficient.

issue.title: [CDCSDK] Avoid updating WAL retention of table if it is already large enough

labels.name: kind/enhancement
labels.description: This is an enhancement of an existing feature

issue.body:
Jira Link: [DB-8223](https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-8223)
### Description

Upon a CDC stream creation (both xCluster and CDCSDK), we issue an AlterTable call to update its WAL retention time.

We can skip doing that if the WAL retention time of the table is already high enough.

Note that there are xCluster tests which assume that there will always be an AlterTable, so those tests would also need to be updated according. Example - `CDCServiceTestDurableMinReplicatedIndex.TestBootstrapProducer`.

### Source connector version

NA

### Connector configuration

NA

### YugabyteDB version

NA

### Issue Type

kind/enhancement

### Warning: Please confirm that this issue does not contain any sensitive information

- [X] I confirm this issue does not contain any sensitive information.

[DB-8223]: https://yugabyte.atlassian.net/browse/DB-8223?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiNWRkNTljNzYxNjVmNDY3MDlhMDU5Y2ZhYzA5YTRkZjUiLCJwIjoiZ2l0aHViLWNvbS1KU1cifQ

comment.body:
@hari90 Lets only do this for xCluster and not for CDCSDK. We plan on performing other steps as part of AlterTable for consistent snapshot, so we must always make the AlterTable.

cc: @asrinivasanyb

comment.body: In a non unique secondary index the ybbasectid (which is the ybctid of the table, the internal representation of its primary key) must be part of the key to have unique entries. It is at the end of the indexed columns so doesn't impact the range scan. And it is used to access the table's row to get the columns that are not in the index (in an Index Scan that is not an Index Only Scan)

commits.message:
[#19696] Interpret arguments to remote_build.py as arguments to yb_build.sh if possible

Summary: Arguments to yb_build.sh are frequently specified on the remote_build.py command line. Make it easier to use that tool by interpreting the full list of arguments to remote_build.py as arguments to yb_build.sh in case they could not be correctly parsed as remote_build.py arguments.

Test Plan:
Jenkins: skip

bin/run_codecheck

`bin/remote_build.py --lto=full release`

(should correctly forward the arguments to yb_build.sh)

`bin/remote_build.py --lto=nosuchmode release`

The output should be similar to:

```
Invalid LTO type: nosuchmode
Stack trace:
  /Users/myusername/code/yugabyte-db15/yb_build.sh:1449 main
Error parsing arguments to remote_build.py: unrecognized arguments: --lto=nosuchmode
Also could not interpret them as arguments to yb_build.py (see the error above). If you want to combine arguments to both scripts, specify remote_build.py arguments first, then --, then arguments to yb_build.sh.
```

Reviewers: sergei, timur

Reviewed By: sergei

Subscribers: ybase

Differential Revision: https://phorge.dev.yugabyte.com/D29712
